Graphical abstract Catalysis of chromite spinel MCr2O4 (M = 3d metal etc.) depends very much on M but the reason is unclear. Herein, CO oxidation by cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) was investigated as one example, using DFT + U. Surface termination of these chromites is determined by available oxidation state of M. Catalytic activity of the most stable surface termination increases following the order cubic CuCr2O4(111) < cubic MgCr2O4(111) < cubic CoCr2O4(111)-A < cubic ZnCr2O4(111) < cubic CoCr2O4(111)-B < tetragonal CuCr2O4(100), where surface termination A is as stable as different termination B. This order agrees with experimental findings. Volcano plot is obtained for catalytic activity against oxygen vacancy formation energy (E Ov), which is clearly explained by electronic structure of M. This plot indicates that the E Ov is a good descriptor for the CO oxidation activity of chromite spinels. Keywords Chromite spinel MCr2O4 DFT + U CO oxidation O vacancy Reaction mechanism Volcano plot 1 Introduction Chromite spinel MCr2O4 (M = Mg, Co, Cu, Zn, etc.) is crucially important as cathode materials [1], gas sensors [2], photo-catalysts [3], and heterogeneous catalysts for such various reactions as methanol synthesis [4], combustion of soot[5] and hydrocarbon [6,7], and CO oxidation [8–10]. Recently, ZnCr2O4 has been newly applied to a tandem-type three-way-catalyst (TWC) with CuCo2O4 by Satsuma and coworkers [11]. Because this catalyst consists only of base-metal elements, it is recognized now as one of the promising TWCs without platinum group metal (PGM). In this catalyst, ZnCr2O4 is used for propene oxidation at the first stage and CuCo2O4 is used for CO-NO reaction at the second stage. Important point of this catalyst is that propene oxidation activity of ZnCr2O4 prevails CO oxidation activity; if CO oxidation to CO2 is performed perfectly by ZnCr2O4, NO reduction cannot be performed by CuCo2O4 in the next stage. This is surprising because CO oxidation is not difficult in general and also MCr2O4 is known as a good catalyst for CO oxidation [8–10], as mentioned above. Thus, we address two important open questions; why ZnCr2O4 is not very active for CO oxidation and how we can control the CO oxidation catalytic activity of MCr2O4. Chromite spinel (MCr2O4) has a cubic crystal phase for M = Mg, Co, and Zn but a tetragonally distorted crystal structure for M = Cu due to strong Jahn–Teller effect [12–14], indicating that the crystal structure significantly depends on the coexistent M atom. CO oxidation activity of MCr2O4 also depends on the M atom and the activity increases following the order cubic-MgCr2O4 < cubic-ZnCr2O4 < cubic-CoCr2O4 < tetragonal-CuCr2O4 [11,15]. Similarly, the activity and the selectivity of zinc–chromium oxides in syngas (CO/H2) conversion to methanol depend on Zn:Cr ratio [4,16,17]. These results clearly show that catalytic activity of chromite spinel significantly depends on the coexistent M atom. However, we do not know how and why the M modulates catalytic activity of chromite spinels. Thus, we address the third open question; what role(s) the M atom plays in determining the catalytic activity of MCr2O4. Earlier studies showed that CuCr2O4 spinel underwent a tetragonal-to-cubic phase transition at 853 K [18] and 653 K [19], depending on the synthesis method. This means that CuCr2O4 has two possible crystal structures. The catalytic activity of tetragonal CuCr2O4 has been reported [11,15] but that of cubic CuCr2O4 has not. Thus, we address the fourth open question; how much active the cubic CuCr2O4 is and why the catalytic activity differs between these two crystals. To obtain answers to these questions, we need correct knowledge of active site, reaction mechanism, and rate-determining step of catalytic reaction. For obtaining the knowledge, electronic structure calculations are necessary. In the calculation of chromite spinel, we have to construct its reasonable surface model, considering various experimental findings described below: Schmid et al. [20] experimentally revealed that (100) surface was populated on the tetragonal CuCr2O4 crystal. Hosseini et al. [21] synthesized various MCr2O4 nanocrystals (M = Co, Cu, and Zn) and found that all those nanocrystals had similar morphology, suggesting that these MCr2O4 spinels have similar surface structure. Toshev et al. [22] and Milosevic et al. [23] experimentally disclosed that ZnCr2O4 single crystal had octahedral structure with (111) surface. Liu et al. [4] and Gay et al. [24] reported in their theoretical studies that ZnCr2O4 had a truncated octahedron morphology exposing mainly (111) surface (92.7%). Thus, it is likely concluded that cubic MCr2O4 (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) has (111) surface and tetragonal CuCr2O4 has (100) surface. Here, we have to remember that four and eight kinds of surface termination (Tx, x = 1–4 or 1–8) are possible in the tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) and cubic MCr2O4(111) surfaces, respectively. Because the surface structure deeply relates to catalytic properties, as reported by Roesch et al. [25], we need to employ the most stable and the most populated surface termination. Recently, Sauer et al. [26] investigated surface termination of Fe3O4(111)/Pt(111) using vibrational spectroscopy. However, such experimental research has not been reported yet on chromite spinel. Thus, we have to explore the surface termination using theoretical approach. But, it is not easy to determine the most stable surface termination by calculating theoretically surface energy (γ), because we cannot construct symmetrically tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) and cubic MCr2O4(111) slab models keeping the chemical stoichiometry of MCr2O4. Though Liu and coworkers [4] firstly evaluated the γ value of cubic ZnCr2O4(111) surface with different terminations by adding extra Zn, Cr, or O atom(s) in the slab model, relative stabilities of various surface terminations of tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) and cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, and Cu) have not been discussed at all. Though it is likely that the surface termination significantly depends on the M atom, the dependency of the surface termination on the M has been unclear. Therefore, we address the fifth open question; which surface termination is the most stable in these chromite spinels and how the M atom determines relative stability of surface termination. Despite of aforementioned important open questions, theoretical studies of catalytic oxidation reaction by MCr2O4 have been limited so far except for a few of pioneering works by several groups. Muhler and coworkers [16] reported that the surface O atom was more active for CO adsorption than cation sites on ZnCr2O4(100) surface, using DFT + U method. Dai et al. [27] and Hu et al. [28] revealed that the low-coordinated O atom of the Co3O4(110) surface participated in CO oxidation reaction with oxygen vacancy (Ov) formation, using DFT + U method. Similarly, Sauer et al. [29] and Taketsugu et al. [30] reported the importance of Ov formation in surface chemistry of ceria and titania, respectively. Several DFT studies also disclosed that O2, CO, NO, and glycerol molecules were preferentially adsorbed at Cu and/or Cr sites on cubic CuCr2O4(100) surface [31–33]. However, systematic theoretical study has not been reported yet about full catalytic cycle of CO oxidation and impact of the M atom on the Ov formation and catalytic activity. Also, no clear answer has been presented to aforementioned open questions. Here, we carried out the first comprehensive theoretical study of CO oxidation reaction by cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surfaces. We selected CO oxidation reaction for theoretical analysis, because CO oxidation is one of typical catalytic reactions and these chromite spinels have been experimentally employed for CO oxidation [11,15], as mentioned above. Through this study, we wish to provide theoretical understanding about reaction mechanism, rate-determining step, reactivity of surface O atom, Ov formation, and roles of M in determining stability of surface termination and catalytic activity for CO oxidation. We hope our systematic study and careful analysis provide the guideline on selecting appropriate M atom to enhance or suppress catalytic activity for CO oxidation. 2 Computational details and models 2.1 Methods Spin-polarized DFT calculations were carried out using plane wave basis sets for valence electrons and projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials for core electrons [34,35], as implemented in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [36,37], where the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE)[38] functional was employed. Cutoff energy of plane wave basis set was set to be 450 eV. Monkhorst–Pack k-point meshes of 5 × 5 × 1 and 4 × 3 × 1 were used for calculations of cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surfaces, respectively. To describe strong electron correlation in the chromate spinel, Hubbard + U correction (DFT + U) was employed. The Ueff parameter was taken from the previous DFT studies, as follows: Ueff = 4.0 eV for Cr [16,39,40], 0.0 eV for Mg and Zn [16,41,42], 4.0 eV for Co [43–45], and 5.0 eV for Cu [46,47]. Here, we tested if these Ueff values presented reasonable results by comparing the CO adsorption energy on cubic MCr2O4 (M = Co, Cu, and Zn) among PBE [38], PBE + U, and such hybrid functionals as B3LYP [48–50], B3PW91 [51], and wB97x [52], where the Gaussian 09 program[53] was employed for calculations with hybrid functionals and the VASP was employed for calculations with PBE and PBE + U, using cluster model in both; details are shown in Fig. S1, Table S1, and pages S3–S4 in the Supporting Information (SI). Though different DFT functionals present somewhat different adsorption energies, the difference in CO adsorption energy between PBE + U and B3LYP is not very large; the difference is 0.33 eV, 0.10 eV, and 0.19 eV for CoCr2O4, CuCr2O4, and ZnCr2O4, respectively. It is likely that these U values are useful in this work. Geometry optimization was carried out using convergence criteria 1.0 × 10−4 eV for total energy and 0.01 eV/Å for maximum force. Transition state was optimized using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [54,55]. In the NEB calculations, eight images were used and the convergence criteria were 1.0 × 10−4 eV for total energy and 0.05 eV/Å for maximum force. For each optimized transition state structure, vibrational frequencies were calculated at the same level of theory to determine whether the optimized geometry is minimum or saddle point. The Gibbs free energy of X gaseous molecule was calculated using Eq. (1) [56–58] at T = 500 K and P = 1 atm, because these conditions are close to the experiments [11]. (1) G X T , P = μ X T , P = E X t o t a l + μ X T , P 0 + k B T ln ( P X P 0 ) where E X t o t a l stands for DFT calculated energy of isolated X molecule in gas phase (including zero point energy correction), μ X T , P 0 is chemical potential of X at temperature T, which was taken from thermodynamic tables, and the last term corresponds to contributions by temperature and partial pressure of X gaseous molecule. In this work, the Gibbs energy change was employed for adsorption of X gaseous molecule to surface and desorption of X molecule from surface to gas phase, because entropy change is significantly large in these steps. However, potential energy was used for discussion of other elementary steps because the potential energy change does not differ very much from the Gibbs energy change in the elementary steps in which adsorption and desorption of molecule do not occur and all the species are adsorbed on the surface. This means that vibrational entropy change is neglected here. The Bader charge analysis was made using the program developed by Henkelman group [59]. The Lobster program package[60,61] was used for the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis. Integration of the COHP up to the Fermi level (ICOHP) can be used as an indicator of bond strength [62,63], where negative ICOHP value means bonding interaction. Activation energy (E a) and reaction energy (ΔE) are defined, as follows: E a = E TS − E IS and ΔE = E FS − E IS, where E IS, E TS, and E FS are the Gibbs energies of initial state (IS), transition state (TS), and final state (FS) of each elementary step, respectively, when gaseous molecule participates in the elementary step, but they are potential energies when gaseous molecule does not participate in the elementary step. 2.2 Models Under syngas (CO/H2) reaction conditions, MCr2O4 surface undergoes reduction by CO/H2 to form Ov site [4]. Under CO oxidation conditions, however, H2 does not exist but a lot of O2 molecules exist, suggesting that Ov site is absent before the reaction. Hence, we employed surface model without Ov site. For CuCr2O4, we employed cubic structure with (111) surface and tetragonal one with (100) surface for calculations because both structures have been reported [12–14,18–21]. For other chromite spinels (M = Mg, Co, and Zn), the cubic structure with (111) surface was employed [4,21–24]. Their lattice constants evaluated by DFT calculations agree with experimental values with small deviations; a = b = c = 8.453 Å, 8.463 Å, 8.429 Å, and 8.459 Å for cubic MgCr2O4, CoCr2O4, CuCr2O4, and ZnCr2O4, respectively, where deviation is 1.4% [41], 1.5% [45], 1.2% [64], and 1.6% [41], and a = b = 6.107 Å and c = 7.964 Å for tetragonal CuCr2O4, where deviation is 1.3% [20]. These results indicate that the present DFT calculation is reliable for geometry optimization. Optimized cubic (space group Fd 3 ¯ m) and tetragonal (space group I41/amd) spinel structures of bulk MCr2O4 are shown in Fig. S2 in the SI, and their CrO and MO distances (in Å) are listed in Table S2. All these structures consist of MO4 tetrahedral and edge-sharing CrO6 octahedral units. Relative stabilities of various surface terminations of cubic MCr2O4(111) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surfaces were compared using fully-optimized p(1 × 1) slab model with inversion symmetry, where thickness of 14.5 Å was employed at least and the slab was separated from each other by vacuum region with length of 15 Å, as shown in Figures S3–S4 in the SI. For investigating CO oxidation, the p(1 × 1) slab model maintaining the chemical stoichiometry (MCr2O4) was used with thickness of about 9.0 Å, where the vacuum region was taken to be 15 Å. The horizontal size of the p(1 × 1) slab model is about 6.0 × 6.0 Å and 6.0 × 8.0 Å for cubic MCr2O4(111) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surface, respectively. These slab models were constructed using 12 atomic layers, where the bottom 4 layers were fixed and the rest of the slab including adsorbates was allowed to relax. Total energy was corrected for dipole moment induced by inversion asymmetry of these slab models. We confirmed if this slab model is reasonable by changing the thickness of slab and vacuum layer and if the results of p(1x1) surface model are reasonable by comparing with those of p(2x2) model; see Fig. S5, Table S3, and Fig. S11 in the SI. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stable surface termination At first, relative stabilities of all eight possible surface terminations of cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) were investigated. Above results indicate that relative stability of surface termination depends on the M element. It is important to elucidate how the M element determines the relative stability of the surface termination, because the surface structure deeply relates to the catalytic activity. Prior to the discussion, we need to remember characteristic features of Mg, Co, Cu, Zn, and Cr atoms. Mg and Zn atoms always have +II oxidation state with 3s0 and 3d104s0 valence electron configurations in a formal sense, respectively, and the other oxidation state is unlikely. Co and Cu atoms have +II oxidation state with 3d7 and 3d9 valence electron configurations in CoCr2O4 and CuCr2O4, respectively. But, it is noted that Co atom tends to have +III oxidation state with 3d6 valence electron configuration but scarcely has +I oxidation state with 3d8 valence electron configuration in metal oxide, suggesting that its positive charge tends to increase but hardly decreases at the surface. Cu atom has +I and +II oxidation states with 3d10 and 3d9 valence electron configurations, respectively, but scarcely has +III oxidation state with 3d8 valence electron configuration in metal oxide, suggesting that its positive charge tends to decrease but hardly increases at the surface. Cr atom has +III oxidation state with 3d3 valence electron configuration in MCr2O4 but can have higher oxidation states as well known, suggesting that the Cr positive charge could increase at the surface. In cubic MgCr2O4 and ZnCr2O4, the Cr electronic structure plays important role in determining the surface structure because Mg and Zn always have +II oxidation state. In the T3 surface termination, the Cr atomic charge at the surface is the closest to that in the bulk, as shown in Table 1 . Consequently, the T3 is the most stable in cubic MgCr2O4 and ZnCr2O4. In cubic CoCr2O4 and CuCr2O4, it is likely that Co and Cu atoms also participate in determining the relative stability of the surface termination because their oxidation states are flexible, as mentioned above. The Co atomic charge is moderately larger in T4 than in the bulk, moderately smaller in T3 than in the bulk, but much smaller in T8 than in the bulk. Because the Co atomic charge hardly decreases, the T8 is not stable but the T3 and T4 are similarly stable in cubic CoCr2O4. In cubic CuCr2O4, the Cu atomic charge considerably increases at T3 and T4 surfaces but moderately at T8, suggesting that the T8 is more stable than the T3 and T4 because the Cu atomic charge does not like to increase at the surface. In tetragonal CuCr2O4, both Cu and Cr participate in determining the most stable surface termination; we wish to skip detailed discussion because the discussion is similar. It should be concluded that the possible oxidation state of M is an important factor for determining the stability of cubic MCr2O4(111) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surface terminations. These stable surface terminations will be discussed below. Because the T1, T2, etc. are arbitrary name representing surface termination here (Fig. S3 in the SI) and they do not have any meaning, we will rename the T3, T4, and T8 of cubic MCr2O4(111) and the T4 of tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) to A, B, C, and D surface terminations, respectively, hereinafter. For brevity, their names are abbreviated to MC-A (M = Mg, Co, and Zn), CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D, respectively, where superscripts “C” and “T” represent “cubic” and “tetragonal”, respectively. On these stable surfaces, four kinds of surface O atoms are found depending on different coordination environment; for instance, MgC-A, ZnC-A, and CoC-A have one O atom (named Oa) bound with three Cr atoms and three O atoms (named Ob) bound with one M and two Cr atoms (Fig. 2A). CoC-B has three O atoms (named Oc) bound with two Cr atoms besides one Oa atom (Fig. 2B). CuC-C has three O atoms (named Od) bound with one Cr and one Cu atoms (Fig. 2C). CuT-D has four Ob and two Oc atoms (Fig. 2D); the superscripts “a” to “d” represent differences in coordination number and coordination partner of the surface O atom, hereinafter. The coordination number of the surface O atom is an important factor for the reactivity of the surface O atom, which will be discussed below. 3.2 Adsorptions of O2 and CO molecules to chromite spinel surface We investigated O2 adsorption to the most stable surface termination of cubic MCr2O4(111) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100), because O2 adsorption to metal oxide is important in heterogeneous catalysis, as reported by Sauer et al. [65,66]. However, O2 adsorption energy is calculated to be small (around −0.01 ~ −0.30 eV) on all these surfaces, where O2 molecule is adsorbed at the M site; see Fig. S8 in the SI for O2 adsorption structures. Consistent with the small adsorption energy, the MO distance is very long and the OO distance (1.232–1.235 Å) is almost the same as that of a free O2 molecule (1.234 Å). In the case of ZnCr2O4, we investigated O2 adsorption to the Zn atom because the surface Zn atom is three-coordinated but found that the O2 binding energy is very small (−0.09 eV), the OO distance differs little from that of free O2 molecule, and the ZnO distance is long (2.367 Å), as shown in Fig. S8(A). These results lead to the concludion that O2 is hardly adsorbed to these surfaces and a peroxide species is not formed. In CO adsorption, we explored all possible adsorption structures and found three adsorption structures were stable on cubic MCr2O4(111) surface and four adsorption structures were stable on tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surface, as shown in Fig. 3 , while other adsorption structures changed to one of these stable adsorption structures during geometry optimization, as described in page S11 in the SI. CO adsorption with two neighboring O atoms in a bridging manner is the most stable on all these surfaces, as shown by 2O_bridge in Fig. 3. In this adsorption structure, the CO distance of the CO molecule is elongated to about 1.2 Å, the OS COS angle is small (about 107°–109°), and two OS CO distances are short (about 1.344–1.458 Å), where the superscript “S” represents O atom on surface. These geometrical features indicate that CO adsorbed structure with two surface OS atoms resembles a carbonate-type CO3 structure. Similar carbonate-type adsorption structure was reported in CO adsorption on Fe3O4(111)[67] and CO2 adsorption on Ti3O6 – [30]. Taking ZnC-A as an example, we calculated activation barrier (E a) for CO adsorption at the 2Ob_bridge site and found that it was 0.07 eV relative to CO in gas phase and 0.21 eV relative to physisorped CO. Because this E a value is small, it is likely concluded that CO adsorption occurs with nearly no barrier. Besides 2O_bridge site, CO adsorption occurs at the M_on-top and the MOb_bridge sites on the MC-A surface, but their adsorption energies (BE CO) are much smaller than that of 2O_bridge site (Fig. 3). On the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces, the next strongest CO adsorption occurs at the O_on-top site with considerably large BE CO value. On the CuC-C and CuT-D, CO adsorption occurs at the Cu_on-top site but their BE CO values are very small like that at M_on-top site of the MC-A surface. Thus, it should be concluded that the surface O atom was more reactive for CO than cation sites on all these surface terminations; this is consistent with the theoretical results of CO adsorption site on ZnCr2O4(100) [16] and Co3O4(110)[27] surfaces. Because CO molecules exist in excess in CO oxidation reaction, we investigated the second CO adsorption to these surfaces. On the MC-A (M = Mg, Co, and Zn) surface, the second CO adsorption is endergonic; the Gibbs energy change ΔG° is 0.08–0.44 eV (evaluated at T = 500 K and P = 1 atm throughout this work) at both the MOb_bridge and the M_on-top site. However, the ΔG° by the second CO adsorption is significantly negative, −1.27 eV for the Oc_on-top site in the CoC-B case, −1.74 eV for the Od_on-top site in the CuC-C case, and −1.55 eV for the ObOc_bridge site in the CuT-D case. These results indicate that CO coverage differs between the MC-A (M = Mg, Co, and Zn) and the other surfaces. On the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces, therefore, we investigated CO oxidation reaction in the presence of two adsorbed CO molecules, while on the MC-A surface we investigated CO oxidation in the presence of one adsorbed CO molecule. 3.3 CO oxidation reaction on cubic MgCr2O4(111), CoCr2O4(111), and ZnCr2O4(111) with the A surface termination Geometry changes in CO oxidation on the ZnC-A surface are presented in Fig. 4 as one example because similar geometry changes are observed on the MgC-A and CoC-A surfaces; see Fig. S9 in the SI for geometry changes in the MgC-A and CoC-A cases. As was discussed above, CO is adsorbed at the 2Ob_bridge site to afford a carbonate-like intermediate 1Zn . Then, the CO leaves the surface as CO2 through a transition state TS1Zn to afford free CO2 molecule and oxygen vacancy (Ov) on the surface (named 2Zn ) with considerable endergonicity (ΔE = 0.91 eV, ΔG° = 0.18 eV) and significantly large activation energy (E a = 1.00 eV). The loss of strong CrO and ZnO bonds is the origin of the large endergonicity. In TS1Zn , the O 1 CO S1 angle of CO2 is 157° and the CrO S1 and MO S1 distances are moderately elongated compared to those in 1Zn . After the CO2 desorption, 2Zn undergoes O2 adsorption at the Ov site to afford O2-adsorbed surface 3Zn with somewhat large exoergonicity (ΔG° = −0.62 eV). In 3Zn , the O 2 atom of the O2 molecule occupies the Ov site, the other O 3 atom interacts with the Zn atom, and the O 2 O 3 distance (1.445 Å) is considerably longer than in a free O2 molecule (1.234 Å), suggesting that the O2 molecule is activated very much. The similar dioxygen species adsorbed at the defect site of ceria surface was reported by spectroscopic study [65]. Another possibility is CO adsorption at the Ov site of the ZnC-A surface. We investigated O-bound and C-bound CO adsorption structures and found that both were endergonic (ΔG° = 0.22 and 0.52 eV, respectively); see Fig. S10 in the SI. Thus, only O2 adsorption occurs at the Ov site. Then, the second CO molecule is adsorbed at the 2Ob_bridge site to afford CO-adsorbed surface 4Zn with somewhat large exoergonicity (ΔG° = −0.63 eV), while the CO adsorption does not occur at the M_on-top site; it is endergonic (ΔG° = 0.24 eV), as was discussed above. This second CO molecule reacts with the terminal O 3 atom of the adsorbed O2 to form a CO2-adsorbed species 5Zn through a transition state TS2Zn . In TS2Zn , the ZnO 3 distance is considerably elongated by 0.309 Å but the CO 3 distance becomes considerably short by 0.812 Å, while the O 2 O 3 distance is marginally elongated by 0.008 Å (Fig. 4). In 5Zn , the second CO2 molecule interacts with the O S2 atom. The short O S2 CO distance (1.460 Å) and the acute O3 CO4 angle (129°) indicate that the CO2 interaction with the surface is strong and the geometry of the CO2 moiety resembles one part of adsorbed carbonate species; see 5Zn in Fig. 4. Then, the second CO2 dissociates from the surface through a transition state TS3Zn to reproduce the original surface ZnC-A. In this transition state, the O S2 CO distance is considerably elongated to 1.925 Å and the O 3 CO 4 angle somewhat increases to 148°. These results indicate that the first CO2 formation occurs via the Eley–Rideal mechanism and the second occurs via the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism. As shown in Fig. 5 A, the first CO2 desorption occurs with moderate to considerable endergonicity and significantly large activation energy; ΔG° = 0.18 eV, 0.61 eV, and 1.06 eV, and E a = 1.00 eV, 1.18 eV, and 1.38 eV for the ZnC-A, CoC-A, and MgC-A surfaces, respectively. The next O2 and CO adsorptions occur with significant exoergonicity, as shown by the steps 2 → 3 and 3 → 4, respectively. The second CO2 formation occurs via a transition state TS2 with a moderate E a and extremely large exothermicity. The last step is the second CO2 desorption, which occurs through a transition state TS3 with a tiny E a value in the ZnC-A and CoC-A cases but a somewhat E a (0.62 eV) in the MgC-A case. Rate-determining step (RDS) is the first CO2 desorption with the Ov formation and the catalytic activity increases following the order MgC-A < CoC-A < ZnC-A, which agrees with the experimental finding showing that ZnCr2O4 exhibits higher activity than MgCr2O4 at T ≥ 550 K. Their considerably large E a values for the first CO2 desorption are consistent with the experimental result that both ZnCr2O4 and MgCr2O4 are nearly inert for CO oxidation at low temperature.11 3.4 CO oxidation reaction on cubic CoCr2O4(111)-B, cubic CuCr2O4(111)-C, and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100)-D surface terminations Cubic CoCr2O4(111) has comparably stable B surface termination (CoC-B) besides the A surface termination (CoC-A). As shown in Fig. 6 , CO oxidation on the CoC-B surface occurs in a similar manner to that on the CoC-A surface except that two CO molecules, C 1 O 1 and C 2 O 2 , are already adsorbed to the surface before CO oxidation starts, as discussed above. C 2 O 2 interacts with one O S atom, as shown by 2Co in Fig. 6, while C 1 O 1 interacts with two O S atoms. Because the ΔG° (−1.27 eV) for the C 2 O 2 adsorption is much smaller than that (−2.41 eV) for the C 1 O 1 adsorption, C 2 O 2 is more reactive than C 1 O 1 . It dissociates from the surface as the first CO2 molecule with Ov formation through a transition state TS1Co to afford free CO2 and Ov on the surface 3Co . In TS1Co , the CrO S1 distance is considerably elongated to 2.805 Å by 0.520 Å, the C 2 O S1 distance becomes shorter to 1.170 Å, and the O 2 C 2 O S1 angle is almost 180° (Fig. 6). This CO2 geometry is almost the same as that of free CO2 molecule. After the first CO2 desorption, one O2 molecule is adsorbed at the Ov site of 3Co to afford an O2-adsorbed surface 4Co . In 4Co , the terminal O 4 atom of the O2 moiety seems to take a good position for interacting with C 1 O 1 bound with the O S2 and O S3 atoms. C 1 O 1 reacts with this terminal O 4 atom through a transition state TS2Co to afford a CO2-adsorbed surface 5Co . In TS2Co , the C 1 O 4 distance becomes considerably shorter by 1.048 Å. Consistent with this significantly large change in the C 1 O 4 distance, the C 1 O S2 distance is considerably elongated by 1.023 Å and the O 3 O 4 distance is somewhat elongated by 0.078 Å. In 5Co , C 1 O 1 interacts with the O 4 and O S3 atoms and the O S2 atom is bound with two Cr atoms. In this 4Co → 5Co step, therefore, the O S2 C 1 O 1 bond is broken and the O 4 C 1 O 1 bond is formed, indicating that this step is recognized as OCO bond exchange reaction. In 5Co , the C 1 O 1 bond distance is 1.204 Å and the other C 1 O S3 and C 1 O 4 bond distances are 1.352 Å and 1.393 Å, suggesting that this C 1 O3 moiety resembles a carbonate species adsorbed to the surface. The last step is the second CO2 desorption starting from 5Co through a transition state TS3Co . In TS3Co , the O 3 O 4 bond is elongated very much by 0.596 Å, the C 1 O 4 distance becomes short by 0.103 Å, while the C 1 O S3 distance and the O 1 C 1 O 4 angle change little. These moderate geometry changes in the O 1 C 1 O 4 moiety suggest that TS3Co is reactant-like. The similar geometry changes are observed in the CO oxidation on the CuC-C and CuT-D surfaces, as shown by Fig. S12 in the SI. These geometry changes lead us to understanding that the first CO2 formation occurs via the Eley–Rideal mechanism and the second occurs via the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism like in the MC-A case. Fig. 5B shows energy changes in CO oxidation on the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces. The E a for the first CO2 desorption is 0.62 eV, 0.36 eV, and 0.43 eV on the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces, respectively, which are much smaller than those on the ZnC-A, MgC-A, and CoC-A surfaces. One reason is that the CO2 molecule has been almost formed on the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces and the other is that the Ov is easily formed on these surfaces, which will be discussed below (Section 3.5) in more details. The E a for TS2 (OCO bond exchange) is 0.71 eV, 1.50 eV, and 0.50 eV on the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces, respectively (Fig. 5B), while the E a for the second CO2 desorption (TS3) is 0.57 eV, 0.61 eV, and 0.30 eV. The small E a for TS3 is consistent with the reactant-like TS3. Thus, RDS is the OCO bond exchange at TS2. Combining these results with those of the MC-A surface, the catalytic activity for CO oxidation increases following the order CuC-C (1.50) < MgC-A (1.38) < CoC-A (1.18) < ZnC-A (1.00) < CoC-B (0.71) < CuT-D (0.50), where in parenthesis is the E a (in eV) for RDS. This order is consistent with the experimental findings that the activity increases following the order cubic-MgCr2O4 < cubic-ZnCr2O4 < cubic-CoCr2O4 < tetragonal-CuCr2O4 [11,15]. It is also noted that cubic CuCr2O4(111) is much less active than tetragonal CuCr2O4(100). 3.5 Importance of oxygen-vacancy (Ov) formation in CO oxidation In the CO oxidation on the MC-A surface (M = Mg, Co, and Zn), RDS is the first CO2 desorption, which occurs simultaneously with the Ov formation. In the CO oxidation on the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces, on the other hand, RDS is the second CO2 formation with OCO bond exchange. This difference of the MC-A surface from the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces arises from the fact that the Ov formation energy (E Ov) is much smaller in the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces than in the MC-A surface, as summarized in Table 2 . These results indicate that the E Ov value is one of the important factors for determining reaction mechanism and RDS. Here, we will compare the E Ov among the MC-A (M = Mg, Co, and Zn), CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces. The E Ov is defined by Eq. (15); (15) E Ov = E Ov/slab + E O2,gas/2 − E slab where E slab is total energy of slab model before Ov formation, E O2,gas is total energy of dioxygen molecule in gas phase, and E Ov/slab is total energy of the slab model with one Ov. The E Ov value increases following the order CuC-C (0.27) < CuT-D (0.90) < CoC-B (1.27) < ZnC-A (2.50) < CoC-A (3.00) < MgC-A (3.09), as shown in Table 2, where in parenthesis represents E Ov value (in eV). This trend is the same as the increasing order of the E a for the first CO2 desorption, CuC-C (0.36) < CuT-D (0.43) < CoC-B (0.62) < ZnC-A (1.00) < CoC-A (1.18) < MgC-A (1.38), where in parenthesis is the E a (in eV) for the first CO2 desorption. Here, we address two open questions: (1) Why does the E Ov increase following the order ZnC-A < CoC-A < MgC-A on the A surface? And, (2) why is the E Ov value much smaller in the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces than in the MC-A surface? The first question is important for understanding the catalytic activity of the MC-A surface (M = Mg, Co, and Zn), because the E a for the RDS is almost parallel to the E Ov value on these surfaces, as discussed above. In the Ov formation, the M and Cr positive charges decrease (becomes less positive), as shown by Δ q M and Δ q C r in Table 2, where Δ q M and Δ q C r are changes in atomic charge; a negative value means decrease in positive atomic charge. The negative Δ q M and Δ q C r values indicate that M and Cr atoms receive electron density from the O atom leaving the surface. Interestingly, the Zn receives considerably large electron density but the Co and Mg moderately receive electron density. The Cr receives considerably large electron density in the MgC-A but somewhat in the ZnC-A and moderately in the CoC-A surface. Fig. 7 shows the difference density (Δρ = ρOv/slab + ρO − ρslab) of the MC-A surface by the Ov formation, where ρO, ρslab, and ρOv/slab are electron densities of isolated O atom, the MC-A surface without Ov, and the MC-A surface with one Ov, respectively. Apparently, electron density considerably decreases around the Ov site, as shown by green area in Fig. 7, but moderately increases around the Cr atom, as shown by orange area. On the other hand, electron density around the M atom changes in a different manner depending on the M; it increases around the Zn to a similar extent to that around the Cr, changes little around the Mg, and increases in some regions but decreases in the other regions around the Co atom; note that this complicated change in electron density around the Co atom may arise from participation of d orbitals. In the Co case, the green region (density decrease) seems to componsate the orange region (density increase), suggesting that the sum of electron densities does not change very much. These results lead us to the conclusion that the ZnII is good but the CoII and MgII are not good for the Ov formation. The tendencies of Zn, Co, and Mg to receive electron density are easily understood on the basis of their available oxidation states. Mg has very stable +II oxidation state, as well known, and it has the smallest electronegativity in these metals. Consequently, MgII does not like to receive electron density and the E Ov value of the MgC-A surface is the largest in these three chromites. Zn has also stable +II oxidation state, but it can receive electron density more easily than the MgII because Zn is transition metal element; see Fig. S13 and explanation below it in the SI (page S15). Accordingly, the E Ov of the ZnC-A surface is smaller than that of the MgC-A surface. Though Co is also transition metal element, Co has +II and +III oxidation states but scarcely has +I oxidation state in metal oxides, suggesting that its positive charge tends to increase but hardly decreases. These are the reasons why the E Ov (3.00 eV) of the CoC-A surface is larger than that (2.50 eV) of the ZnC-A surface. Thus, it is concluded that the available oxidation states of M determine the Ov formation energy. Essentially the same understanding was presented above on the relative stability of the surface termination structure, indicating that the M plays important roles in determining both the surface termination and the Ov formation energy in the similar manner. The second question is as to the reason why the E Ov value is smaller in the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces than in the MC-A surface (Table 2). The answer to this question is necessary for understanding the reasons why RDS changes to the OCO bond exchange in these chromites. The OS atom has two coordination bonds on these surfaces but three coordination bonds on the MC-A surfaces; remember that the MC-A surface has one Oa atom bound with three Cr atoms and three Ob atoms bound with two Cr and one M atoms, the CoC-B surface has one Oa atom and three Oc atoms bound with two Cr atoms, the CuC-C surface has three Od atoms bound with one Cr and one Cu atom, and the CuT-D surface has two Oc atoms besides four Ob atoms. Apparently, the Oc and Od atoms more easily dissociate from the surface to form the Ov site than the Oa and Ob atoms because of their smaller coordination numbers than those of the Oa and Ob atoms. Thus, the Ov site is more easily formed on the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces than on the MC-A surface. 3.6 Importance of MOS bond strength of cubic CoCr2O4(111)-B, cubic CuCr2O4(111)-C, and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100)-D surfaces In the CO oxidation on the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces, RDS is the second CO2 formation with the OCO bond exchange. In this transition state (TS2), the O S2 CO bond is broken but the O 4 CO bond is formed (Fig. 6), suggesting strongly that the E a for TS2 depends on the reactivity of the terminal O 4 atom of the adsorbed O2 moiety and the O S2 CO bond strength. The reactivity of the terminal O 4 atom seems similar among these surfaces, as follows; the O 3 O 4 bond distance of the adsorbed O2 moiety does not differ very much among these surfaces and the terminal O 4 atom has similar atomic charge; −0.02 e in the CoC-B surface, −0.06 e in the CuC-C surface, and −0.09 e in the CuT-D surface. Thus, it is likely that the O S2 CO bond strength is mainly responsible for the difference in the E a for TS2. The O S2 CO bond distance increases following the order CuC-C (1.350 Å) < CoC-B (1.392 Å) < CuT-D (1.448 Å), which agrees with the decreasing order of the E a value for TS2, as shown in Table 3 . In the bulk, the O atomic charge is more negative than these O S2 atoms (Table 3), indicating that the surface O S2 atom is electron-deficient and the O S2 atom wants to receive electron density from the interaction partner CO molecule. Hence, it is expected that the less negatively charged O S2 atom forms the stronger O S2 CO bond to increase the E a for TS2. Actually, the O S2 atom becomes more negatively charged following the order CuC-C < CoC-B < CuT-D and the ΔG° for C 1 O 1 adsorption becomes less negative following this order, indicating that the OS CO bond becomes weaker following the same order. This is further confirmed by COHP analysis; the ICOHP ( O s 2 - C O ) value becomes less negative following the order CuC-C > CoC-B > CuT-D, as shown in Table 3, indicating that the OS CO bond becomes weaker in this order. Consequently, the E a for TS2 decreases following the order CuC-C > CoC-B > CuT-D, as shown in Table 3. These results can be understood from the viewpoint of the coordination number and the coordination partner of the O S2 atom, as follows: The O S2 atom is bound with one Cu and two Cr atoms in the CuT-D surface, two Cr atoms in the CoC-B surface, and one Cr and one Cu atom in the CuC-C surface. Because the Cr has +III oxidation state and the Co and Cu have +II oxidation state in these chromites, the Cr−O bond is stronger than the Co−O and Cu−O bonds and the O S2 atom is more negatively charged when it is bound with CrIII than with CoII. Thus, the O S2 bonding interaction with the surface metal atoms becomes stronger following the order CuC-C < CoC-B < CuT-D and the negative charge of the O S2 atom increases following the same order, which leads to the decreasing order of E a, CuC-C > CoC-B > CuT-D. It is concluded that the coordination number and the coordination partner of the O S2 atom determine the catalytic activity of these chromites because these two factors determine the O S2 binding strength with the surface and the negative charge of the O S2 atom. We need to remember here that the coordination number and the coordination partner of the OS atom depend on the surface termination and the available oxidation state of M determines the surface termination. 3.7 Unified understanding of CO oxidation activity of cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surfaces In the previous two sections, we separately discussed E a of RDS in CO oxidation reaction by cubic MCr2O4(111)-A (M = Mg, Co, and Zn), cubic CoCr2O4(111)-B, cubic CuCr2O4(111)-C, and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100)-D on the basis of the E Ov values and the O S CO bond strength, respectively. Here, we wish to present unified understanding of CO oxidation catalysis of all these chromites. It is likely that the O S CO bond strength relates to the E Ov value because the O S CO bond is expected to be weak when the O S atom is strongly bound with the surface Cr and M atoms, as discussed above. We investigated the relationship between the E Ov and the CO adsorption energy (BE CO) because BE CO is a measure of the CO bonding interaction with the O S atom; BE CO = E slab:CO – (E slab + E CO), where E slab:CO, E slab, and E CO are total energies of the CO-adsorbed slab model, the slab model without CO, and a free CO molecule, respectively. Apparently, the BE CO value is almost parallel to the E Ov value, as shown in Fig. 8 A, indicating that the O S CO bond is strong when the E Ov is small, as expected above. Then, we plotted the activation energy E a for RDS against the E Ov value. As shown in Fig. 8B, a very clear volcano plot is obtained. When the E Ov value is large, RDS is the first CO2 desorption with the Ov formation because the O S atom is strongly bound with the surface Cr and M atoms. When the E Ov value is small, the Ov is easily formed and therefore RDS is the second CO2 formation with O S CO bond cleavage. In the former case, the low E Ov value results in the high catalytic activity. In the latter case, on the other hand, the overly low E Ov value results in the overly strong O S CO bond, as shown in Fig. 8A, and therefore the E a for the O S CO bond cleavage becomes large. It is concluded that both overly large E Ov and overly small E Ov are not good for CO oxidation catalysis of chromite spinels. The volcano plot of Fig. 8B suggests that the largest activity of chromite spinel is obtained at E Ov = 1.50–2.00 eV. This is a useful guideline on controlling the CO oxidation catalysis of chromite spinel; because the Ov formation energy can be calculated easily, we can predict the activity of chromite spinel for CO oxidation using DFT computations. 4 Conclusions CO oxidation by cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) surfaces was theoretically investigated to elucidate crucially important roles of M in determining reaction mechanism, Ov formation energy, and catalytic activity, using DFT + U computations. Firstly, we investigated the stable surface termination by evaluating the surface energy and found that the available oxidation state of M is important for determining the relative stability of surface termination. Then, we investigated CO oxidation employing the most stable surface termination. Important findings are summarized below: (1) The CO oxidation activity increases following the order CuC-C (1.50) < MgC-A (1.38) < CoCA (1.18) < ZnC-A (1.00) < CoC-B (0.71) < CuT-D (0.50), where in parenthesis is the E a value (in eV) for RDS. This order agrees with the experimental findings [11,15]. (2) On the MC-A (M = Mg, Co, and Zn) surface, the first CO oxidation occurs through the Eley-Rideal mechanism and the second occurs through the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. RDS is the first CO2 desorption with the Ov formation. The Ov formation energy (E Ov) increases following the order ZnC-A (2.50) < CoC-A (3.00) < MgC-A (3.09), where in parenthesis is E Ov (in eV). This order is the same as the increasing order of the E a for CO oxidation. (3) The M receives electron density upon the Ov formation. Hence, the available oxidation states of M are important factor again for determining the E Ov of the MC-A surface. Because Mg always has +II oxidation state and its electronegativity is very small, Mg cannot receive electron density well. Co has +II and +III oxidation states in metal oxides, indicating that Co tends to release the electron density but does not like to receive electron density. Zn always has +II oxidation state but it can receive electron density more easily than the MgII because Zn is transition metal element. Therefore, Zn is the best for the Ov formation and the ZnC-A surface is the most active in these MC-A surfaces. (4) On the CoC-B, CuC-C, and CuT-D surfaces, the first CO oxidation occurs through the Eley-Rideal mechanism and the second occurs through the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism like on the MC-A surface. However, RDS changes to the second CO2 formation with O S CO bond cleavage from the CO2 desorption with Ov formation, because Ov is easily formed due to the lower coordination number of the OS atom. (5) Their catalytic activities depend on the O S CO bond strength which is determined by coordination number and coordination partner of the OS atom: Because the O S atom is electron-deficient compared to the O atom in the bulk, the less negatively charged O S atom wants to receive a lot of electron density from CO to form the stronger O S CO bond with CO molecule. Because the O S is bound with two Cr atoms in the CoC-B, Cr and Cu atoms in the CuC-C, and one Cu and two Cr atoms in the CuT-D, the O S in the CuT-D is the most strongly bound with the surface and the most negatively charged. Thus, the O S atom of the CuT-D does not need to receive a lot of electron density from CO and the O S CO bond is the weakest, leading to the lowest E a value for TS2. Essentially the same discussion can be presented for the reason of the higher activity of the CoC-B than the CuC-C. It is concluded that the available oxidation state and electronic nature of M determine the surface termination, the coordination number and the coordination partner of the O S atom, and therefore, the M determines the catalytic activity of these chromites. Finally, we tried to present unified understanding of the catalytic activity of all these chromite spinels. The relation between the E a of RDS and the E Ov shows a typical volcano plot. This means that both overly large E Ov and overly small E Ov are not good for CO oxidation catalysis of chromite spinels and the largest catalytic activity is obtained around E Ov = 1.50–2.00 eV. This volcano plot is reasonable; when E Ov is small, RDS is the O S CO bond cleavage and the overly small E Ov leads to the overly strong O S CO bond and the large E a value for TS2 (O S CO bond cleavage). When E Ov is large, RDS is CO2 desorption with Ov formation and the overly large E Ov leads to the large E a value for TS1 (CO2 desorption). We wish to propose that the E Ov is a good descriptor for predicting the CO oxidation activity of chromite spines. We believe that these understandings of the role of M provide new insights into catalytic chemistry of MCr2O4 spinels and the guideline on predicting its catalytic activity for CO oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Catalysis of chromite spinel MCr2O4 (M = 3d metal etc.) depends very much on M but the reason is unclear. Herein, CO oxidation by cubic MCr2O4(111) (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn) and tetragonal CuCr2O4(100) was investigated as one example, using DFT + U. Surface termination of these chromites is determined by available oxidation state of M. Catalytic activity of the most stable surface termination increases following the order cubic CuCr2O4(111) < cubic MgCr2O4(111) < cubic CoCr2O4(111)-A < cubic ZnCr2O4(111) < cubic CoCr2O4(111)-B < tetragonal CuCr2O4(100), where surface termination A is as stable as different termination B. This order agrees with experimental findings. Volcano plot is obtained for catalytic activity against oxygen vacancy formation energy (E Ov), which is clearly explained by electronic structure of M. This plot indicates that the E Ov is a good descriptor for the CO oxidation activity of chromite spinels.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical insight into oxidation catalysis of chromite spinel MCr2O4 (M = Mg, Co, Cu, and Zn): Volcano plot for oxygen-vacancy formation and catalytic activity
